Journal.Title: Environmental science and pollution research international

Article.ArticleTitle: Ethylenediurea (EDU) protects inbred but not hybrid cultivars of rice from yield losses due to surface ozone.

AbstractText: The rising concentration of ground-level ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) reduces crop yield via increased oxidative stress. Application of ethylenediurea (EDU) protects plants from O<sub>3</sub> and could thereby serve as a means to estimate the crop yield losses due to ambient O<sub>3</sub> (AO<sub>3</sub>). However, no study but a few exceptions has ever compared the yield loss estimates from EDU application with those from O<sub>3</sub> elevation experiments. Here, we estimated yield loss to AO<sub>3</sub> in rice cultivars across the 3 types, indica, japonica, and hybrid, by an EDU application in the field, and compared the yield losses with those estimated with dose-response relationships based on O<sub>3</sub> elevation experiments. Relative yield loss (RYL) in the EDU application was estimated at 16% across the rice types on an assumption of a 100% efficiency for protection of crop yield by EDU. This estimate of RYL was close to the 15% RYL estimated from the O<sub>3</sub> elevation experiments when a common sensitivity to O<sub>3</sub> is assumed across the cultivars. The rice yield loss due to AO<sub>3</sub> was thus consistent between the two approaches supporting the idea of EDU application for the yield loss estimation. When only hybrids are focused, however, the RYL from EDU application (16%) was much lower than the 34% RYL from the O<sub>3</sub> elevation experiments, which indicates only a 37% yield protection by EDU in the hybrid rice. The incomplete protection by EDU and its genetic variability indicates the need to quantify the efficiency of protection from AO<sub>3</sub>-induced yield loss as estimated with O<sub>3</sub> manipulating experiments.
